title: 113_s2519
content:
The Act is titled the "National Cybersecurity Protection Act of 2014" and defines key terms such as "Center," "critical infrastructure," "cybersecurity risk," "information sharing and analysis organization," and "information system." The Act defines key terms such as "cybersecurity risk" as threats to information systems and related consequences caused by unauthorized access, use, disclosure, or destruction of information. The Act defines key terms related to cybersecurity incidents, information sharing organizations, and information systems. It establishes a national cybersecurity and communications integration center within the Department to handle specific responsibilities. The Center, led by the Secretary appointed under section 103(a)(1)(H), functions as a Federal civilian interface for sharing cybersecurity information, coordinating responses, and facilitating cross-sector collaboration to address cybersecurity risks and incidents. The Center, led by the Secretary, conducts integration and analysis of cybersecurity risks, shares analysis with entities, provides technical assistance and incident response, and offers security recommendations to strengthen information systems. The Center is composed of representatives from Federal and non-Federal entities, including sector-specific agencies, civilian and law enforcement agencies, elements of the intelligence community, State and local governments, information sharing organizations, and owners of critical information systems. The Center for cybersecurity and communications activities includes a designated Federal official for operational coordination and other appropriate representatives. In the event of an incident, the Secretary may grant temporary access to the Center. The Center ensures timely sharing of actionable information related to cybersecurity risks and integrates it with other relevant information tailored to specific sectors. The sector's characteristics prioritize activities based on risk levels and involve seeking expertise from industry-specific, academic, and national laboratory sources. Coordination is continuous, collaborative, and inclusive across sectors. The sector coordinating councils, information sharing and analysis organizations, and other non-Federal partners are key players in coordinating activities based on risk levels and seeking expertise from various sources. Coordination is continuous, collaborative, and inclusive across sectors. The Center for cybersecurity works to share information on risks and incidents efficiently, prevent duplication, safeguard data, and comply with privacy laws. The Under Secretary has sole discretion over including governmental or private entities in the Center. Providing assistance or information to one entity does not guarantee the same for others. The Secretary must provide recommendations on expediting cybersecurity information-sharing agreements between the Center and non-Federal entities within 180 days of this Act's enactment. The recommendations should address the development of a scalable form that maintains privacy and other protections in cybersecurity. The Secretary must provide recommendations on expediting cybersecurity information-sharing agreements with non-Federal entities, including necessary authorities and resources. Additionally, an annual report on the Center must be submitted to relevant committees for the next three years. The annual report on the Center must include an assessment of its capability, the number of non-Federal entity representatives participating, requests from non-Federal entities, response times, delays in security clearance processing, and the agencies involved in such delays. The annual report on the Center includes an assessment of its capability, non-Federal entity participation, request response times, delays in security clearance processing, obstacles to resolving requests, reasons for denials, and information sharing with critical infrastructure sectors. SEC. 6. GAO REPORT.
The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on the Center's cybersecurity mission effectiveness within 2 years of the Act's enactment. 

SEC. 7. CYBER INCIDENT RESPONSE PLAN; CLEARANCES; BREACHES.
Subtitle C of title II of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 will be amended to include a Cyber Incident Response Plan under the Under Secretary's authority. The Under Secretary, in collaboration with various entities, will develop and maintain cyber incident response plans for critical infrastructure. The Secretary will facilitate security clearance applications for sector coordinating councils and information sharing organizations. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will update data breach notification policies to ensure timely reporting to Congress and relevant committees. The agency must report unauthorized acquisition or access within days of discovery, including specific details. The agency must provide a summary of breach information, estimate the number of affected individuals, explain any delays in notification, and provide an estimate of when affected individuals will be notified. The affected agency must notify individuals of a data breach promptly and without delay. The Attorney General or relevant authorities can delay notification if it would disrupt investigations or endanger national security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must report annually on data breaches for the first two years after the Act's enactment. Management and Budget must annually assess agency implementation of data breach notification policies and include the assessment in the report required under section 3543(a)(8) of title 44, United States Code. The intelligence community elements required to provide notice of data breaches shall only notify appropriate congressional committees. No changes to federal agency authority are made by the amendment. Section 1(b) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item after section 226. SEC. 8. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. Prohibits the Secretary from gaining new regulatory authority regarding cybersecurity of private sector critical infrastructure. Private entities are not required to request assistance or implement recommendations from the Secretary.
